title: Gustavo Diaz
section: Mayors Reduce Spending in Response to Increased Monitoring to Minimize Electoral Backlash
text:
Mayors Reduce Spending in Response to Increased Monitoring to Minimize Electoral Backlash
 
Gustavo Diaz
McMaster University
gustavodiaz.org
diazg2@mcmaster.ca
 
Slides and paper: talks.gustavodiaz.org

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Why does monitoring improve performance?


1. Top-down enforcement


Monitoring alone reduces inefficiency
Ex-post sanctions, legal investigations



2. Bottom-up accountability


Information helps voters hold politicians accountable
Those found underperforming are voted out of office

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Bottom-up accountability?







Source: Incerti (2020)

title: Gustavo Diaz
section: Lack of sanctions does not imply lack of accountability
text:
Lack of sanctions does not imply lack of accountability






 Politicians learn about monitoring efforts before they occur and adjust behavior accordingly

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Argument:
Incumbents anticipate bottom-up accountability


Politicians selected for auditing expect increased scrutiny on their performance
This is true even if monitoring does not uncover irregularities
News of monitoring alone attracts voter attention to performance in office
Those seeking reelection have incentives to take action before news are public


 
. . .

Monitoring  Update performance in office

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Why spending?











Incumbent faces tradeoff between two economic activities (Persson and Tabellini 2000)

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Why reducing spending?











Prospective voters: Incumbents want to signal good type

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Data: Anti-corruption audits in Brazil






Controladoria Geral da União (CGU)
2003-2015
Lottery selects municipalities to audit use of federal funds
Make results public
40 lotteries, 2,187 audits






Picture: Jorge Hage, head of CGU ca. 2010, announces municipalities selected for auditing

title: Gustavo Diaz
text: Distribution of audits over time

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Research design


Mayoral elections in 2004, 2008, 2012, 2016
Treatment: Municipality selected for auditing (binary)
Outcome: Spending per capita (logged)

 

QOI: Average treatment effect of audit selection on spending
Distinguish between reelection-eligible vs. term-limited

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Results: Election-year outcomes











Clustered standard errors by municipality and state-term fixed effects

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Results: Audit timing











Clustered standard errors by municipality and state-term fixed effects

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Also in the paper

No effect on spending in other years
Not an artifice of top-down enforcement
Not an artifice of targeted spending
Effect more pronounced with higher uncovered corruption

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Conclusion

Mayors decrease spending in reaction to audit selection
More pronounced under reelection incentives


Implications

Bottom-up accountability still matters
Politicians learn to navigate monitoring efforts over time
Long-term monitoring still helpful
But at the expense of improving service provision?

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Interviews: No social/political control

Politics for them does not exist, they are in the business [of selling drugs]. Politics is the business of other people, they are interested in having economic means quickly, but politics is not their strong suit


 
They are not well-organized enough to be involved in other things

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Interviews: Limited to economic mechanisms

Politics for them does not exist, they are in the business [of selling drugs]. Politics is the business of other people, they are interested in having economic means quickly, but politics is not their strong suit


 
They are not well-organized enough to be involved in other things

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Conclusion

Criminal governance can persist under low crime, high state presence
But no attempt at social/political control


Implications

Current explanations may be biased towards high violence cases
Rethinking theoretical scope conditions

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Three prevalence estimators
\[
\hat{\tau}_A = \text{Mean}(A_t) - \text{Mean}(A_c)
\]

\[
\hat{\tau}_B = \text{Mean}(B_t) - \text{Mean}(B_c)
\]


\[
\hat{\tau}_{Pooled} = (\hat{\tau}_A + \hat{\tau}_B)/2
\]



See Diaz (2023) and Miller (1984) for details

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Carryover design effects






Design effect (Blair and Imai 2012)


The inclusion of a sensitive item affects how survey participants respond to the baseline items within the list.










Carryover design effect


The inclusion of a sensitive item in one list affects how participants respond to the baseline items in the other list.

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Statistical tests


Goal: Detect asymmetric shift across treatment schedules
Two tests:


Difference-in-differences
Signed-rank test

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Statistical tests


Goal: Detect asymmetric shift across treatment schedules
Two tests:


Difference-in-differences
Signed-rank test

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Difference-in-differences test
\[
\hat{\tau}_1 = \text{Mean}(\text{First list}_t) - \text{Mean}(\text{First list}_c)
\]
\[
\hat{\tau}_2 = \text{Mean}(\text{Second list}_t) - \text{Mean}(\text{Second list}_c)
\]


\(H_0: \hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 = 0\)
Deflation: \(\hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 < 0\)
Inflation: \(\hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 > 0\)
Calculate via regression or randomization inference

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Carryover design effects






Design effect (Blair and Imai 2012)


The inclusion of a sensitive item affects how survey participants respond to the baseline items within the list.










Carryover design effect


The inclusion of a sensitive item in one list affects how participants respond to the baseline items in the other list.

Statistical tests

Difference-in-differences
Signed-rank test

title: Gustavo Diaz

Goal: Detect asymmetric shift across treatment schedules
Two tests:


Difference-in-differences
Signed-rank test

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Difference-in-differences test
\[
\hat{\tau}_1 = \text{Mean}(\text{First list}_t) - \text{Mean}(\text{First list}_c)
\]
\[
\hat{\tau}_2 = \text{Mean}(\text{Second list}_t) - \text{Mean}(\text{Second list}_c)
\]


\(H_0: \hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 = 0\)
Deflation: \(\hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 < 0\)
Inflation: \(\hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 > 0\)
Calculate via regression or randomization inference

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Questions


Have you lied about having COVID symptoms?
Would you bribe a police officer to avoid a traffic ticket?
Have you been offered goods or favors for your vote?
Do you know anyone with ties to a militant organization?
Would you oppose a black family moving next door?
Would you allow Muslim immigrants to become citizens?

title: Gustavo Diaz
section: What do these have in common?
text:
What do these have in common?


They are sensitive questions
We can only learn about them using surveys
But asking about them directly leads to misreporting
This form of measurement error is called sensitivity bias

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Three prevalence estimators

\[
\hat{\tau}_A = \text{Mean}(A_t) - \text{Mean}(A_c)
\]

difference_in_means(count ~ sensitive, subset = list == "A", data = df)



\[
\hat{\tau}_B = \text{Mean}(B_t) - \text{Mean}(B_c)
\]

difference_in_means(count ~ sensitive, subset = list == "B", data = df )



\[
\hat{\tau}_{Pooled} = (\hat{\tau}_A + \hat{\tau}_B)/2
\]

lm_robust(count ~ sensitive + list, clusters = id, data = df)

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Carryover design effects






Design effect (Blair and Imai 2012)


The inclusion of a sensitive item affects how survey participants respond to the baseline items within the list.










Carryover design effect


The inclusion of a sensitive item in one list affects how participants respond to the baseline items in the other list.

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Difference-in-differences test
\[
\hat{\tau}_1 = \text{Mean}(\text{First list}_t) - \text{Mean}(\text{First list}_c)
\]
\[
\hat{\tau}_2 = \text{Mean}(\text{Second list}_t) - \text{Mean}(\text{Second list}_c)
\]


\(H_0: \hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 = 0\)
Deflation: \(\hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 < 0\)
Inflation: \(\hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 > 0\)




# For fixed-randomized design
lm_robust(count ~ sensitive*first, clusters = id, data = df)

Stephenson’s signed rank test
\[
\widetilde{T} = \sum_{i=1}^N \text{sgn} \{(z_i - (1-z_i)) (Y_{i1} - Y_{i2})\} \times \tilde{q}_i
\]
\[
\tilde{q}_i = {q_i-1 \choose m-1} \text{ for } q_i \geq m
\]
\[
\tilde{q}_i = 0 \text{ for } q_i < m
\]
\[
\text{with } 1 \leq m \leq N
\]


 See Stephenson (1981) and Rosenbaum (2020) for details

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Carryover design effects






Design effect (Blair and Imai 2012)


The inclusion of a sensitive item affects how survey participants respond to the baseline items within the list.










Carryover design effect


The inclusion of a sensitive item in one list affects how participants respond to the baseline items in the other list.

title: Gustavo Diaz
text:
Difference-in-differences test
\[
\hat{\tau}_1 = \text{Mean}(\text{First list}_t) - \text{Mean}(\text{First list}_c)
\]
\[
\hat{\tau}_2 = \text{Mean}(\text{Second list}_t) - \text{Mean}(\text{Second list}_c)
\]


\(H_0: \hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 = 0\)
Deflation: \(\hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 < 0\)
Inflation: \(\hat{\tau}_1 - \hat{\tau}_2 > 0\)




# For fixed-randomized design
lm_robust(count ~ sensitive*first, clusters = id, data = df)




There is also a signed-rank test (Diaz 2023)

text:
Stephenson’s signed rank test
\[
\widetilde{T} = \sum_{i=1}^N \text{sgn} \{(z_i - (1-z_i)) (Y_{i1} - Y_{i2})\} \times \tilde{q}_i
\]
\[
\tilde{q}_i = {q_i-1 \choose m-1} \text{ for } q_i \geq m
\]
\[
\tilde{q}_i = 0 \text{ for } q_i < m
\]
\[
\text{with } 1 \leq m \leq N
\]


 See Stephenson (1981) and Rosenbaum (2020) for details
